Faster Rates for Compressed Federated Learning with Client-Variance Reduction

Haoyu Zhao Princeton University, NJ (). haoyu@princeton.edu    Konstantin Burlachenko KAUST, Saudi Arabia (, ). konstantin.burlachenko@kaust.edu.sa peter.richtarik@kaust.edu.sa    Zhize Li Carnegie Mellon University, PA (); Corresponding author. zhizeli@cmu.edu    Peter Richtárik22footnotemark: 2
Abstract

Due to the communication bottleneck in distributed and federated learning applications, algorithms using communication compression have attracted significant attention and are widely used in practice. Moreover, the huge number, high heterogeneity and limited availability of clients result in high client-variance. This paper addresses these two issues together by proposing compressed and client-variance reduced methods COFIG and FRECON. We prove an O​((1+ω)3/2​NS​ϵ2+(1+ω)​N2/3S​ϵ2)𝑂superscript1𝜔32𝑁𝑆superscriptitalic-ϵ21𝜔superscript𝑁23𝑆superscriptitalic-ϵ2O(\frac{(1+\omega)^{3/2}\sqrt{N}}{S\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{(1+\omega)N^{2/3}}{S\epsilon^{2}}) bound on the number of communication rounds of COFIG in the nonconvex setting, where N𝑁N is the total number of clients, S𝑆S is the number of clients participating in each round, ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is the convergence error, and ω𝜔\omega is the variance parameter associated with the compression operator. In case of FRECON, we prove an O​((1+ω)​NS​ϵ2)𝑂1𝜔𝑁𝑆superscriptitalic-ϵ2O(\frac{(1+\omega)\sqrt{N}}{S\epsilon^{2}}) bound on the number of communication rounds. In the convex setting, COFIG converges within O​((1+ω)​NS​ϵ)𝑂1𝜔𝑁𝑆italic-ϵO(\frac{(1+\omega)\sqrt{N}}{S\epsilon}) communication rounds, which, to the best of our knowledge, is also the first convergence result for compression schemes that do not communicate with all the clients in each round. We stress that neither COFIG nor FRECON needs to communicate with all the clients, and they enjoy the first or faster convergence results for convex and nonconvex federated learning in the regimes considered. Experimental results point to an empirical superiority of COFIG and FRECON over existing baselines.

keywords:
federated learning, distributed optimization, communication compression, variance reduction

1 Introduction

With the proliferation of mobile and edge devices, federated learning [24, 36] has emerged as a framework for training machine learning models over geographically distributed and heterogeneous devices. In federated learning, there is a central server and there are plenty of clients. The central server communicates with the clients to train a machine learning model using the local data stored on the clients. Federated learning is often modeled as a distributed optimization problem [23, 24, 36, 17, 44]. Let 𝒟𝒟{\mathcal{D}} be the entire dataset distributed across all N𝑁N clients/devices/workers/machines, where each client i𝑖i has a local dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖{\mathcal{D}}_{i}. The goal is to solve the following optimization problem without sharing the local datasets with the central server:

(1) min𝒙∈ℝd⁡{f​(𝒙;𝒟):=1N​∑i=1Nf​(𝒙;𝒟i)},subscript𝒙superscriptℝ𝑑assign𝑓𝒙𝒟1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁𝑓𝒙subscript𝒟𝑖\displaystyle\min_{{\bm{x}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\left\{f({\bm{x}};{\mathcal{D}}):=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}f({\bm{x}};{\mathcal{D}}_{i})\right\},

where f​(𝒙;𝒟i):=𝔼di∼𝒟i​f​(𝒙;di)assign𝑓𝒙subscript𝒟𝑖subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝒟𝑖𝑓𝒙subscript𝑑𝑖f({\bm{x}};{\mathcal{D}}_{i}):=\mathbb{E}_{d_{i}\sim{\mathcal{D}}_{i}}f({\bm{x}};d_{i}). Here, 𝒙∈ℝd𝒙superscriptℝ𝑑{\bm{x}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is the model, f​(𝒙;𝒟)𝑓𝒙𝒟f({\bm{x}};{\mathcal{D}}), f​(𝒙;𝒟i)𝑓𝒙subscript𝒟𝑖f({\bm{x}};{\mathcal{D}}_{i}), and f​(𝒙;di)𝑓𝒙subscript𝑑𝑖f({\bm{x}};d_{i}) denotes the loss function of the model 𝒙𝒙{\bm{x}} on the entire dataset 𝒟𝒟{\mathcal{D}}, the local dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖{\mathcal{D}}_{i}, and a random data sample disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i}, respectively.

1.1 Communication efficiency

Communication between the central server and the clients is a main bottleneck for the federated learning applications, especially when the number of clients is large, the clients such as mobile phones have limited bandwidth, and/or the machine learning model has a lot of parameters. Thus, it is crucial to design federated learning algorithms to reduce the overall communication cost, which takes into account both the number of communication rounds and the communication cost per communication round for reaching the desired accuracy. Based on these two quantities, there are two lines of approaches for communication-efficient federated learning: 1) local methods: in each communication round, clients run multiple local update steps before communicating with the central server, hoping to reduce the number of communication rounds; 2) compressed methods: clients send compressed communication messages to the central server, in the hope of reducing the communication cost per communication round.

Both categories have gained significant attention. For local methods, a small sample of examples include FedAvg [36], Local-SVRG [10], SCAFFOLD [18] and FedPAGE [48]. On the other hand, many compressed methods are proposed, including but not limited to [1, 22, 37, 14, 31, 33, 9, 4, 34, 42, 35, 47]. In particular, the current state-of-the-art guarantees in convex and nonconvex settings are provided by CANITA [34] and MARINA [9], respectively.

In this paper, we focus on compression to enhance communication efficiency. See Section 2.2 for more discussions.

1.2 Methods with variance reduction

Variance reduction, or data-variance reduction is a well-studied technique in standard/centralized finite-sum optimization, which aims to achieve a faster convergence rate. There are many optimization algorithms using the variance reduction technique, including SVRG [16, 40], SAGA [6], SCSG [26], SARAH [38], SPIDER [7], SSRGD [27, 32], and PAGE [29, 28]. These algorithms usually compute the stochastic gradients using a subset of data samples (obtain better convergence results) and periodically compute the full gradient using all data samples (reduce data-variance). For example, the convergence result for standard gradient descent (GD) (which always computes full gradients) is O​(N/ϵ2)𝑂𝑁superscriptitalic-ϵ2O(N/\epsilon^{2}) in the nonconvex setting, while the variance-reduced methods SARAH/SPIDER/PAGE obtain much better result O​(N/ϵ2)𝑂𝑁superscriptitalic-ϵ2O(\sqrt{N}/\epsilon^{2}).

In the federated learning setting, we decompose the data-variance into two parts: the client-variance and the clients’ local-variance. The client-variance captures the dissimilarity of data stored on different heterogeneous clients, i.e., the variance induced by different datasets 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖{\mathcal{D}}_{i} (see problem (1)), which is the variance faced by the central server. The local-variance or local-data-variance is induced by the local data samples stored on each client, and it is the data-variance faced by the local clients if they compute local stochastic gradients not local full gradients. We point out that the client-variance is the main issue for federated learning because of the data heterogeneity issue, and even if one can compute the local full gradients using the whole local dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖{\mathcal{D}}_{i} on each client (i.e., remove the local-variance), the client-variance faced by the central server still exists.

Moreover, directly applying the variance reduction algorithms like SVRG/PAGE in the federated learning has the following drawbacks: (1) These variance-reduced methods usually need to periodically compute the full gradient using all data samples (reduce data-variance), which leads to communication with all clients periodically in the federated learning setting. However, federated learning applications typically involve a lot of clients, for example, Google Keyboard (Gboard) [12, 39] involves billions of mobile phones, and thus it is impractical to communicate with all the clients in a communication round to reduce the client-variance. (2) These variance-reduced algorithms do not use communication compression to further reduce the communication cost. On the other hand, the existing communication compression algorithms usually need to communicate with all the clients in each communication round (see Tables 1). Among the compressed algorithms that support partial participation (PP) (do not need to communicate with all clients in each round), previous methods either need to communicate with all the clients (FP) using uncompressed messages periodically (PP-MARINA [9]), or do not enjoy the faster convergence rate of variance reduction (FedGLOMO [5], EF21-PP [8]). Thus, we consider the following natural and important question:

Can we incorporate client-variance reduction with communication compression
in the federated learning setting?

1.3 Our contributions

In this paper, we design COFIG and FRECON algorithms for federated learning. Both algorithms support communication compression and fully partial participation, and achieve the first/faster convergence using client-variance reduction technique (see Table 1) under any heterogeneity. Concretely, we summarize our main contributions as follows:

  1. 1.

    We design COFIG algorithm, which to our best knowledge, is the first algorithm that supports partial participation and communication compression for the general non-strongly convex federated learning setting (see the convex column in Table 1). For the nonconvex setting, COFIG successfully supports communication compression and fully partial participation (PP) (unlike PP-MARINA) and enjoys the convergence speedup (unlike FedGLOMO and EF21-PP) by using client-variance reduction (see the nonconvex column in Table 1). Besides, COFIG also supports the client’s local-variance (Section 2.1) and PP simultaneously, which is more practical than other compressed algorithms such as FedGLOMO and PP-MARINA in federated learning.

  2. 2.

    For the nonconvex setting, we further design a new FRECON algorithm based on COFIG, which can converge much faster than COFIG (see the nonconvex column in Table 1). In particular, FRECON converges within O​((1+ω)​N/(S​ϵ2))𝑂1𝜔𝑁𝑆superscriptitalic-ϵ2O((1+\omega)\sqrt{N}/(S\epsilon^{2})) communication rounds, matches the convergence result of PP-MARINA. However, FRECON supports fully partial participation with a subset clients and thus is more practical than PP-MARINA which requires periodical full participation (FP) with uncompressed messages. Note that periodic FP needs to periodically synchronize all clients/devices in federated learning, which is usually impossible or unaffordable.

2.1 Assumptions about the functions

In this paper, we consider two general settings: the nonconvex setting and the convex setting.

In the nonconvex setting, the functions {fi}i∈[N]subscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑁\{f_{i}\}_{i\in[N]} are arbitrary functions that satisfy the following smoothness assumption [16, 6, 38, 49, 7, 29], and we assume that the unbiased local stochastic gradient oracle ∇~​fi​(𝒙)~∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙\tilde{\nabla}f_{i}({\bm{x}}) has bounded local variance [36, 18, 48], which is also standard in the federated learning literature. We use ∇~b​fi​(𝒙)subscript~∇𝑏subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙\tilde{\nabla}_{b}f_{i}({\bm{x}}) to denote the stochastic gradient oracle that uses a minibatch size b𝑏b, which is the average of b𝑏b independent unbiased stochastic gradients ∇~​fi​(𝒙)~∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙\tilde{\nabla}f_{i}({\bm{x}}).

{assumption}

[Smoothness] The functions {fi}i∈[N]subscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑁\{f_{i}\}_{i\in[N]} are L𝐿L-smooth if there exists L≥0𝐿0L\geq 0 such that for any client i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N], ‖∇fi​(𝒙1)−∇fi​(𝒙2)‖≤L​‖𝒙1−𝒙2‖norm∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝒙1∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝒙2𝐿normsubscript𝒙1subscript𝒙2\left\|\nabla f_{i}({\bm{x}}_{1})-\nabla f_{i}({\bm{x}}_{2})\right\|\leq L\left\|{\bm{x}}_{1}-{\bm{x}}_{2}\right\|, for all 𝒙1,𝒙2∈ℝdsubscript𝒙1subscript𝒙2superscriptℝ𝑑{\bm{x}}_{1},{\bm{x}}_{2}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

{assumption}

[Bounded local-variance] There exists a constant σ≥0𝜎0\sigma\geq 0 such that for any client i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N] and any 𝒙∈ℝd𝒙superscriptℝ𝑑{\bm{x}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, 𝔼​‖∇~​fi​(𝒙)−∇fi​(𝒙)‖2≤σ2𝔼superscriptnorm~∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙2superscript𝜎2\mathbb{E}\left\|\tilde{\nabla}f_{i}({\bm{x}})-\nabla f_{i}({\bm{x}})\right\|^{2}\leq\sigma^{2}. Then for a stochastic gradient oracle with minibatch size b𝑏b, we have 𝔼​‖∇~b​fi​(𝒙)−∇fi​(𝒙)‖2≤σ2b𝔼superscriptnormsubscript~∇𝑏subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙2superscript𝜎2𝑏\mathbb{E}\left\|\tilde{\nabla}_{b}f_{i}({\bm{x}})-\nabla f_{i}({\bm{x}})\right\|^{2}\leq\frac{\sigma^{2}}{b}.

For the convex setting, besides the smoothness and bounded local-variance assumptions, we also need the function f𝑓f to be convex. Formally, we use the following assumption.

{assumption}

[Convexity] A function f𝑓f is convex if ∀𝒙,𝒚∈ℝd,f​(𝒚)≥f​(𝒙)+⟨∇f​(𝒙),𝒚−𝒙⟩formulae-sequencefor-all𝒙𝒚superscriptℝ𝑑𝑓𝒚𝑓𝒙∇𝑓𝒙𝒚𝒙\forall{\bm{x}},{\bm{y}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d},f({\bm{y}})\geq f({\bm{x}})+\left<\nabla f({\bm{x}}),{\bm{y}}-{\bm{x}}\right>.

2.2 Compression operators

We now introduce the notion of a randomized compression operator which we use to reduce the total communication bits. We adopt the standard class of unbiased compressors (see Definition 2.1) that was widely used in previous distributed/federated learning literature [1, 22, 37, 14, 31, 9, 34].

Definition 2.1 (Compression operator).

A randomized map 𝒞:ℝd↦ℝd:𝒞maps-tosuperscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑{\mathcal{C}}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\mapsto\mathbb{R}^{d} is an ω𝜔\omega-compression operator if for all 𝐱∈ℝd𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑{\bm{x}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, it satisfies

(2) 𝔼​[𝒞​(𝒙)]=𝒙,𝔼​[‖𝒞​(𝒙)−𝒙‖2]≤ω​‖𝒙‖2.formulae-sequence𝔼delimited-[]𝒞𝒙𝒙𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝒞𝒙𝒙2𝜔superscriptnorm𝒙2\mathbb{E}[{\mathcal{C}}({\bm{x}})]={\bm{x}},\qquad\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|{\mathcal{C}}({\bm{x}})-{\bm{x}}\right\|^{2}\right]\leq\omega\left\|{\bm{x}}\right\|^{2}.

In particular, no compression (𝒞​(𝐱)≡𝐱𝒞𝐱𝐱{\mathcal{C}}({\bm{x}})\equiv{\bm{x}}) implies ω=0𝜔0\omega=0.

3 COFIG: Fast Compressed Algorithm with Variance Reduction

In this section, we present our COFIG algorithm (Algorithm 1), which supports gradient compression, fully partial participation, and has better convergence results. In Section 3.1, we introduce our COFIG algorithm, and in Section 3.2, we present the convergence rate of COFIG in both convex and nonconvex settings.

3.1 COFIG algorithm

In our COFIG algorithm, each client i𝑖i maintains the local shift sequence {𝒉it}superscriptsubscript𝒉𝑖𝑡\{{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t}\} and a virtual sequence {𝒘it}superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡\{{\bm{w}}_{i}^{t}\}111Here, the virtual sequence {𝒘it}superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡\{{\bm{w}}_{i}^{t}\} is only used for algorithmic illustration and analysis purpose. In real execution, the clients do not need to maintain {𝒘it}superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡\{{\bm{w}}_{i}^{t}\}., and the server maintains the global shift {𝒉t}superscript𝒉𝑡\{{\bm{h}}^{t}\} and the model 𝒙tsuperscript𝒙𝑡{\bm{x}}^{t} in each round. At a very high-level point of view, the virtual variable 𝒘itsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡{\bm{w}}_{i}^{t} records the model 𝒙𝒙{\bm{x}} in client i𝑖i’s last active communication round, and the shifts {𝒉it}superscriptsubscript𝒉𝑖𝑡\{{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t}\} are used for reducing the variance.

Now, we describe these ingredients in more detail. COFIG can be divided into three steps: (1) clients compute and compress the local gradient information using the current model 𝒙tsuperscript𝒙𝑡{\bm{x}}^{t} and local shifts {𝒉it}superscriptsubscript𝒉𝑖𝑡\{{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t}\}; (2) clients update the local shift {𝒉it+1}superscriptsubscript𝒉𝑖𝑡1\{{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t+1}\} and the virtual sequence {𝒘it+1}superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡1\{{\bm{w}}_{i}^{t+1}\}; and (3) the server updates the model to 𝒙t+1superscript𝒙𝑡1{\bm{x}}^{t+1} and the global shift {𝒉t+1}superscript𝒉𝑡1\{{\bm{h}}^{t+1}\} using the compressed gradient information aggregated from the clients.

In each round t𝑡t, the server first sample two sets of clients 𝒮tsuperscript𝒮𝑡{\mathcal{S}}^{t} and 𝒮~tsuperscript~𝒮𝑡\tilde{\mathcal{S}}^{t}. For clients i∈𝒮t𝑖superscript𝒮𝑡i\in{\mathcal{S}}^{t}, they updates their control sequence {𝒉it}i∈[N]subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒉𝑖𝑡𝑖delimited-[]𝑁\{{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t}\}_{i\in[N]} and the virtual sequence {𝒘it}i∈[N]subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡𝑖delimited-[]𝑁\{{\bm{w}}_{i}^{t}\}_{i\in[N]}, and send the compressed message to the server (Line 4, 5 of Algorithm 1). Note that when we update the local shift, there is a shift step size α𝛼\alpha, which makes the shift 𝒉it+1superscriptsubscript𝒉𝑖𝑡1{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t+1} a biased estimator of ∇fi​(𝒘it+1)∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡1\nabla f_{i}({\bm{w}}_{i}^{t+1}), since

𝔼​[𝒉it+1]=𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝒉𝑖𝑡1absent\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t+1}]= 𝔼​[𝒉it+α​𝒞​(∇~b​fi​(𝒙t)−𝒉it)]=(1−α)​𝒉it+α​∇fi​(𝒙t).𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝒉𝑖𝑡𝛼𝒞subscript~∇𝑏subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒙𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒉𝑖𝑡1𝛼superscriptsubscript𝒉𝑖𝑡𝛼∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒙𝑡\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t}+\alpha{\mathcal{C}}(\tilde{\nabla}_{b}f_{i}({\bm{x}}^{t})-{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t})]=(1-\alpha){\bm{h}}_{i}^{t}+\alpha\nabla f_{i}({\bm{x}}^{t}).

This biased shift is useful for controlling the variance.

Then for the clients j∈𝒮~t𝑗superscript~𝒮𝑡j\in\tilde{\mathcal{S}}^{t}, they compute the estimators and send to the server. Note the compressed message 𝒗jtsuperscriptsubscript𝒗𝑗𝑡{\bm{v}}_{j}^{t} computed by clients j∈𝒮~t𝑗superscript~𝒮𝑡j\in\tilde{\mathcal{S}}^{t} is nearly the same as the compressed message 𝒖itsuperscriptsubscript𝒖𝑖𝑡{\bm{u}}_{i}^{t} computed by clients i∈𝒮t𝑖superscript𝒮𝑡i\in{\mathcal{S}}^{t} except the randomness of compression operator, and we need to compute 𝒗jtsuperscriptsubscript𝒗𝑗𝑡{\bm{v}}_{j}^{t} to decouple the randomness in the nonconvex setting.

Finally, the server updates the model 𝒙tsuperscript𝒙𝑡{\bm{x}}^{t} and the global shift 𝒉tsuperscript𝒉𝑡{\bm{h}}^{t}. From Line 16 of Algorithm Algorithm 1, it is easy to prove that he global shift 𝒉tsuperscript𝒉𝑡{\bm{h}}^{t} is an average of the local shifts {𝒉it}superscriptsubscript𝒉𝑖𝑡\{{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t}\}. To update the model, the server first computes a gradient estimator 𝒈tsuperscript𝒈𝑡{\bm{g}}^{t} using the compressed information aggregated from the clients. The estimator 𝒈tsuperscript𝒈𝑡{\bm{g}}^{t} is an unbiased estimator for ∇f​(𝒙t)∇𝑓superscript𝒙𝑡\nabla f({\bm{x}}^{t}), since

𝔼​[𝒈t]=𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝒈𝑡absent\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[{\bm{g}}^{t}]= 𝔼​[1S​∑i∈𝒮~t𝒞​(∇~b​fi​(𝒙t)−𝒉it)+𝒉t]=𝔼​[1S​∑i∈𝒮~t(∇fi​(𝒙t)−𝒉it)+𝒉t]=∇f​(𝒙t).𝔼delimited-[]1𝑆subscript𝑖superscript~𝒮𝑡𝒞subscript~∇𝑏subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒙𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑡𝑖superscript𝒉𝑡𝔼delimited-[]1𝑆subscript𝑖superscript~𝒮𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒙𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑡𝑖superscript𝒉𝑡∇𝑓superscript𝒙𝑡\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{S}\sum_{i\in\tilde{\mathcal{S}}^{t}}{\mathcal{C}}(\tilde{\nabla}_{b}f_{i}({\bm{x}}^{t})-{\bm{h}}^{t}_{i})+{\bm{h}}^{t}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{S}\sum_{i\in\tilde{\mathcal{S}}^{t}}(\nabla f_{i}({\bm{x}}^{t})-{\bm{h}}^{t}_{i})+{\bm{h}}^{t}\right]=\nabla f({\bm{x}}^{t}).

Note that in real execution, each client only needs to maintain vector 𝒉isubscript𝒉𝑖{\bm{h}}_{i} and the server only need to maintain 𝒉=1N​∑i=1N𝒉i𝒉1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝒉𝑖{\bm{h}}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\bm{h}}_{i}. Thus, Line 8 does not need to be executed by clients j∉𝒮t𝑗superscript𝒮𝑡j\notin{\mathcal{S}}^{t}. Besides, the clients do not need to maintain the sequence 𝒘isubscript𝒘𝑖{\bm{w}}_{i}. We explicitly write out the superscripts and the sequence 𝒘𝒘{\bm{w}} for better illustration and analysis.

Now we point out COFIG in the degenerated cases: 1) the case with no compression (ω=0𝜔0\omega=0) and no clients’ local-variance (∇~b​fi​(𝒙t)=∇fi​(𝒙t)subscript~∇𝑏subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒙𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒙𝑡\tilde{\nabla}_{b}f_{i}({\bm{x}}^{t})=\nabla f_{i}({\bm{x}}^{t})), our COFIG algorithm reduces to the SAGA algorithm [6] for finite-sum optimization; 2) the case with full participation (𝒮t=𝒮~t=[N]superscript𝒮𝑡superscript~𝒮𝑡delimited-[]𝑁{\mathcal{S}}^{t}=\tilde{\mathcal{S}}^{t}=[N]), our algorithm reduces to the DIANA algorithm [37, 14]. As a result, our COFIG enhances the SAGA with communication compression, and generalizes the DIANA without requiring full clients participation.

3.2 Convergence results for COFIG

Now we state the convergence results of COFIG in convex setting (Theorem 3.1) and nonconvex setting (Theorem 3.2). These two theorems show that, by incorporating client-variance reduction with communication compression, COFIG obtains faster convergence results (enjoying the speedup from variance reduction techniques) and supports partial participation (thus more practical for federated learning).

Theorem 3.1 (COFIG in convex case).

Suppose that Section 2.1, Section 2.1, and Section 2.1 hold. By choosing α=11+ω𝛼11𝜔\alpha=\frac{1}{1+\omega}, and η=min⁡{1L​(2+8​(1+ω)/S),S(1+ω)​N,b​S​ϵ2​(1+ω)​σ2}𝜂1𝐿281𝜔𝑆𝑆1𝜔𝑁𝑏𝑆italic-ϵ21𝜔superscript𝜎2\eta=\min\Big{\{}\frac{1}{L(2+8(1+\omega)/S)},\frac{S}{(1+\omega)\sqrt{N}},\frac{bS\epsilon}{2(1+\omega)\sigma^{2}}\Big{\}}, COFIG (Algorithm 1) will find a point x𝑥x such that 𝔼​f​(𝐱)−f∗≤ϵ𝔼𝑓𝐱superscript𝑓italic-ϵ\mathbb{E}f({\bm{x}})-f^{*}\leq\epsilon in the following number of communication rounds

T=O​(Lϵ+(1+ω)​N​LS​ϵ+(1+ω)​σ2b​S​ϵ2).𝑇𝑂𝐿italic-ϵ1𝜔𝑁𝐿𝑆italic-ϵ1𝜔superscript𝜎2𝑏𝑆superscriptitalic-ϵ2T=O\left(\frac{L}{\epsilon}+\frac{(1+\omega)\sqrt{N}L}{S\epsilon}+\frac{(1+\omega)\sigma^{2}}{bS\epsilon^{2}}\right).

Theorem 3.2 (COFIG in nonconvex case).

Suppose that Section 2.1 and Section 2.1 hold. By choosing α=11+ω𝛼11𝜔\alpha=\frac{1}{1+\omega}, and η=min⁡{12​L,S5​L​(1+ω)​N2/3,S5​L​(1+ω)3/2​N,b​S​ϵ220​(1+ω)​σ2}𝜂12𝐿𝑆5𝐿1𝜔superscript𝑁23𝑆5𝐿superscript1𝜔32𝑁𝑏𝑆superscriptitalic-ϵ2201𝜔superscript𝜎2\eta=\min\Big{\{}\frac{1}{2L},\frac{S}{5L(1+\omega)N^{2/3}},\frac{S}{5L(1+\omega)^{3/2}\sqrt{N}},\frac{bS\epsilon^{2}}{20(1+\omega)\sigma^{2}}\Big{\}}, COFIG (Algorithm 1) will find a point x𝑥x such that 𝔼​‖∇f​(𝐱)‖≤ϵ𝔼norm∇𝑓𝐱italic-ϵ\mathbb{E}\left\|\nabla f({\bm{x}})\right\|\leq\epsilon in the following number of communication rounds

O​(Lϵ2+L​(1+ω)​N2/3S​ϵ2+L​(1+ω)3/2​NS​ϵ2+(1+ω)​σ2b​S​ϵ4).𝑂𝐿superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝐿1𝜔superscript𝑁23𝑆superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝐿superscript1𝜔32𝑁𝑆superscriptitalic-ϵ21𝜔superscript𝜎2𝑏𝑆superscriptitalic-ϵ4O\left(\frac{L}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{L(1+\omega)N^{2/3}}{S\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{L(1+\omega)^{3/2}\sqrt{N}}{S\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{(1+\omega)\sigma^{2}}{bS\epsilon^{4}}\right).

Now we interpret the convergence results in Theorem 3.1 and Theorem 3.2. First in the convex setting (Theorem 3.1), COFIG converges to an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-solution with the following total communication cost O​(Sϵ+(1+ω)​Nϵ+(1+ω)​σ2b​ϵ2)𝑂𝑆italic-ϵ1𝜔𝑁italic-ϵ1𝜔superscript𝜎2𝑏superscriptitalic-ϵ2O(\frac{S}{\epsilon}+\frac{(1+\omega)\sqrt{N}}{\epsilon}+\frac{(1+\omega)\sigma^{2}}{b\epsilon^{2}}), by multiplying the communication rounds T𝑇T by S𝑆S. The first two terms in the communication rounds T𝑇T come from the client-variance reduction, and the last term comes from the clients’ local variance. Note that our COFIG algorithm provides the first convergence result which supports partial participation and communication compression in the convex setting (see Table 1). Moreover, our algorithm support clients’ local-variance (Section 2.1), which has more advantages compared with other compressed gradient methods listed in Table 1 and Table 1.

Next in the nonconvex case (Theorem 3.2), COFIG converges to an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-approximate stationary point with the following total communication cost O​(Sϵ2+(1+ω)​N2/3ϵ2+(1+ω)3/2​Nϵ2+(1+ω)​σ2b​ϵ4)𝑂𝑆superscriptitalic-ϵ21𝜔superscript𝑁23superscriptitalic-ϵ2superscript1𝜔32𝑁superscriptitalic-ϵ21𝜔superscript𝜎2𝑏superscriptitalic-ϵ4O(\frac{S}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{(1+\omega)N^{2/3}}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{(1+\omega)^{3/2}\sqrt{N}}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{(1+\omega)\sigma^{2}}{b\epsilon^{4}}). Similar to the convex case, the first two terms come from the client-variance reduction, and the last term comes from the clients’ local variance. The third term in the convergence rate comes from the analysis of the compression methods, and the similar term also shows up in the convergence rate of DIANA, which is the full participation version of COFIG. When there is no local variance (σ2=0superscript𝜎20\sigma^{2}=0), note that except FedGLOMO and PP-MARINA, all other methods in Table 1 need O​(N/ϵ2)𝑂𝑁superscriptitalic-ϵ2O(N/\epsilon^{2}) total communication cost, and our COFIG converges in O​(N2/3/ϵ2)𝑂superscript𝑁23superscriptitalic-ϵ2O(N^{2/3}/\epsilon^{2}). Although FedGLOMO converges in S𝑆\sqrt{S} and PP-MARINA converges in O​(N)𝑂𝑁O(\sqrt{N}), FedGLOMO has a worse dependency on ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon and needs to assume that the individual functions fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} are lower bounded, and PP-MARINA needs to periodically communicate with all the clients with uncompressed message. Moreover, both FedGLOMO and PP-MARINA do not support clients’ local-variance, which makes COFIG more flexible/practical for the federated learning setting. In the next section, we introduce another algorithm FRECON (Algorithm 2) that matches the convergence rate of PP-MARINA in the nonconvex setting, but it does not need to periodically communicate with all of the clients using uncompressed messages unlike PP-MARINA.

Note that by choosing a proper minibatch size b𝑏b, we further improve the convergence rate in terms of the communication rounds when σ𝜎\sigma is large. Formally, we have the following corollary.

Corollary 3.3.

Suppose that Section 2.1 and Section 2.1 hold. If we choose η𝜂\eta properly and b≥σ2ϵ2​N2/3𝑏superscript𝜎2superscriptitalic-ϵ2superscript𝑁23b\geq\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\epsilon^{2}N^{2/3}}, COFIG (Algorithm 1) will find a point x𝑥x such that 𝔼​‖∇f​(𝐱)‖≤ϵ𝔼norm∇𝑓𝐱italic-ϵ\mathbb{E}\left\|\nabla f({\bm{x}})\right\|\leq\epsilon in the following number of communication rounds T=O​(Lϵ2+L​(1+ω)​N2/3S​ϵ2+L​(1+ω)3/2​NS​ϵ2)𝑇𝑂𝐿superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝐿1𝜔superscript𝑁23𝑆superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝐿superscript1𝜔32𝑁𝑆superscriptitalic-ϵ2T=O\left(\frac{L}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{L(1+\omega)N^{2/3}}{S\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{L(1+\omega)^{3/2}\sqrt{N}}{S\epsilon^{2}}\right). If Section 2.1 also holds, i.e. f𝑓f is convex, then if we choose η𝜂\eta properly and b≥σ2ϵ2​N𝑏superscript𝜎2superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑁b\geq\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\epsilon^{2}\sqrt{N}}, COFIG (Algorithm 1) will find a point x𝑥x such that 𝔼​f​(𝐱)−f∗≤ϵ𝔼𝑓𝐱superscript𝑓italic-ϵ\mathbb{E}f({\bm{x}})-f^{*}\leq\epsilon in the following number of communication rounds T=O​(Lϵ+(1+ω)​N​LS​ϵ)𝑇𝑂𝐿italic-ϵ1𝜔𝑁𝐿𝑆italic-ϵT=O\left(\frac{L}{\epsilon}+\frac{(1+\omega)\sqrt{N}L}{S\epsilon}\right).

3.3 Proof sketch and technical novelty

In this part, we highlight our proof sketch and technical novelty, and we focus on the nonconvex setting. Although our COFIG algorithm can be seen as a generalization of both SAGA and DIANA and our convergence results recover the results of both algorithms, the proof of COFIG is totally different and requires new techniques. Previous compressed algorithms, e.g. EF21-PP, EF21, DIANA, directly bound the following term 𝔼​∑i‖𝒉it−∇fi​(𝒙t)‖2𝔼subscript𝑖superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝒉𝑖𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒙𝑡2\mathbb{E}\sum_{i}\left\|{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t}-\nabla f_{i}({\bm{x}}^{t})\right\|^{2}, which describes the difference between the control shift 𝒉itsuperscriptsubscript𝒉𝑖𝑡{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t} and the local full gradient ∇fi​(𝒙t)∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒙𝑡\nabla f_{i}({\bm{x}}^{t}) and usually has the following form

𝔼​∑i‖𝒉it+1−∇fi​(𝒙t+1)‖2≤(1−β)​𝔼​∑i‖𝒉it−∇fi​(𝒙t)‖2+A,𝔼subscript𝑖superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝒉𝑖𝑡1∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒙𝑡121𝛽𝔼subscript𝑖superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝒉𝑖𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒙𝑡2𝐴\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\sum_{i}\left\|{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t+1}-\nabla f_{i}({\bm{x}}^{t+1})\right\|^{2}\leq(1-\beta)\mathbb{E}\sum_{i}\left\|{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t}-\nabla f_{i}({\bm{x}}^{t})\right\|^{2}+A,

where β>0𝛽0\beta>0 is a constant related to S,N,ω𝑆𝑁𝜔S,N,\omega and A𝐴A denotes another term. However, if we directly bound the term 𝔼​∑i‖𝒉it−∇fi​(𝒙t)‖2𝔼subscript𝑖superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝒉𝑖𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒙𝑡2\mathbb{E}\sum_{i}\left\|{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t}-\nabla f_{i}({\bm{x}}^{t})\right\|^{2}, we are not able to get the faster convergence rate N2/3/(S​ϵ2)superscript𝑁23𝑆superscriptitalic-ϵ2N^{2/3}/(S\epsilon^{2}) in terms of the communication rounds and we can only get N/(S​ϵ2)𝑁𝑆superscriptitalic-ϵ2N/(S\epsilon^{2}), which is exactly the convergence rate of EF21-PP. To get the better convergence rate, we need to introduce the virtual sequence {𝒘it}superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡\{{\bm{w}}_{i}^{t}\} and split 𝔼​∑i‖𝒉it+1−∇fi​(𝒙t+1)‖2𝔼subscript𝑖superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝒉𝑖𝑡1∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒙𝑡12\mathbb{E}\sum_{i}\left\|{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t+1}-\nabla f_{i}({\bm{x}}^{t+1})\right\|^{2} into 𝔼​∑i‖𝒉it+1−∇fi​(𝒘t+1)‖2𝔼subscript𝑖superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝒉𝑖𝑡1∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡12\mathbb{E}\sum_{i}\left\|{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t+1}-\nabla f_{i}({\bm{w}}^{t+1})\right\|^{2} and 𝔼​∑i‖∇fi​(𝒘t+1)−∇fi​(𝒙t+1)‖2𝔼subscript𝑖superscriptnorm∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡1∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒙𝑡12\mathbb{E}\sum_{i}\left\|\nabla f_{i}({\bm{w}}^{t+1})-\nabla f_{i}({\bm{x}}^{t+1})\right\|^{2}, and using tighter inequalities to bound these two terms. More specifically, we first apply Young’s inequality to get bounds like

∑i‖𝒉it+1−∇fi​(𝒙t+1)‖2subscript𝑖superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝒉𝑖𝑡1∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒙𝑡12\displaystyle\sum_{i}\left\|{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t+1}-\nabla f_{i}({\bm{x}}^{t+1})\right\|^{2}
(3) ≤(1+β1)​∑i‖𝒉it+1−∇fi​(𝒘t+1)‖2+(1+β1−1)​∑i‖∇fi​(𝒘t+1)−∇fi​(𝒙t+1)‖2absent1subscript𝛽1subscript𝑖superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝒉𝑖𝑡1∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡121superscriptsubscript𝛽11subscript𝑖superscriptnorm∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡1∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒙𝑡12\displaystyle\quad\leq(1+\beta_{1})\sum_{i}\left\|{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t+1}-\nabla f_{i}({\bm{w}}^{t+1})\right\|^{2}+(1+\beta_{1}^{-1})\sum_{i}\left\|\nabla f_{i}({\bm{w}}^{t+1})-\nabla f_{i}({\bm{x}}^{t+1})\right\|^{2}

for all t𝑡t, where β1>0subscript𝛽10\beta_{1}>0 is a constant. Then, we bound the terms separately and get the bounds like

4 FRECON: Faster Algorithm in the Nonconvex Setting

In this section, we present another algorithm FRECON described in Algorithm 2, which can further achieve a faster convergence rate than COFIG in the nonconvex setting when the clients’ local-variance is small. We present our FRECON algorithm in Section 4.1 and show the convergence results in Section 4.2.

4.1 FRECON algorithm

To achieve O​(N/ϵ2)𝑂𝑁superscriptitalic-ϵ2O(\sqrt{N}/\epsilon^{2}) total communication cost in the nonconvex setting, most algorithms use the recursive gradient estimator. Among these algorithms, most of them need to periodically compute full gradients to reduce the variance of the gradient estimator, e.g. SARAH [38], PAGE [29], PP-MARINA [9], FedPAGE [48], except ZeroSARAH [30] which never needs to compute the full gradient. The idea of ZeroSARAH is to maintain another unbiased approximate gradient estimator for the full gradient, and update both the biased recursive and unbiased approximate estimators in each round.

In the federated learning setting with communication compression, recall that in the previous section (Section 3), our COFIG (Algorithm 1) can also generate approximate full gradient estimator 𝒈tsuperscript𝒈𝑡{\bm{g}}^{t} (Line 14 of Algorithm 1) without communicating with all the clients, the idea of FRECON (Algorithm Algorithm 2) is to incorporate recursive gradient estimator together with COFIG (see Line 12 of Algorithm 2).

In each round, the server sample a set of clients 𝒮tsuperscript𝒮𝑡{\mathcal{S}}^{t} to communicate with, and the clients i∈𝒮t𝑖superscript𝒮𝑡i\in{\mathcal{S}}^{t} compute two compressed messages, the first 𝒒itsuperscriptsubscript𝒒𝑖𝑡{\bm{q}}_{i}^{t} is the compressed message for the recursive gradient estimator (Line 5 of Algorithm 2), and the second 𝒖itsuperscriptsubscript𝒖𝑖𝑡{\bm{u}}_{i}^{t} is the compressed message to update the local shift 𝒉isubscript𝒉𝑖{\bm{h}}_{i} and the unbiased full gradient estimator (Line 6 of Algorithm 2). Then, the server computes the gradient estimator (Line 12 of Algorithm 2) by

𝒈t+1=1S​∑i∈𝒮t𝒒it+(1−λ)​𝒈t+λ​(1S​∑i∈𝒮t𝒖it+𝒉t).superscript𝒈𝑡11𝑆subscript𝑖superscript𝒮𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒒𝑡𝑖1𝜆superscript𝒈𝑡𝜆1𝑆subscript𝑖superscript𝒮𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒖𝑡𝑖superscript𝒉𝑡{\bm{g}}^{t+1}=\frac{1}{S}\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{S}}^{t}}{\bm{q}}^{t}_{i}+(1-\lambda){\bm{g}}^{t}+\lambda\left(\frac{1}{S}\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{S}}^{t}}{\bm{u}}^{t}_{i}+{\bm{h}}^{t}\right).

Here, the term 1S​∑i∈𝒮t𝒖it+𝒉t1𝑆subscript𝑖superscript𝒮𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒖𝑡𝑖superscript𝒉𝑡\frac{1}{S}\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{S}}^{t}}{\bm{u}}^{t}_{i}+{\bm{h}}^{t} is exactly the gradient estimator used in COFIG, and the gradient estimator 𝒈tsuperscript𝒈𝑡{\bm{g}}^{t} is a biased estimator. Besides updating the gradient estimator, the server and the clients also need to maintain the global and local shifts 𝒉tsuperscript𝒉𝑡{\bm{h}}^{t} and {𝒉it}superscriptsubscript𝒉𝑖𝑡\{{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t}\} similar to COFIG. Similarly, FRECON with no compression (ω=0𝜔0\omega=0) and no clients’ local-variance reduces to the ZeroSARAH algorithm [30].

4.2 Convergence results for FRECON

Now we state the convergence result for FRECON in the nonconvex setting.

Theorem 4.1 (FRECON in nonconvex case).

Suppose that Section 2.1 and Section 2.1 hold. By choosing α=11+ω𝛼11𝜔\alpha=\frac{1}{1+\omega}, η≤1L​(1+10​(1+ω)2​N/S2)𝜂1𝐿110superscript1𝜔2𝑁superscript𝑆2\eta\leq\frac{1}{L(1+\sqrt{10(1+\omega)^{2}N/S^{2}})}, and the minibatch size b≥O​((1+ω)2​N​σ2S2​ϵ2)𝑏𝑂superscript1𝜔2𝑁superscript𝜎2superscript𝑆2superscriptitalic-ϵ2b\geq O(\frac{(1+\omega)^{2}N\sigma^{2}}{S^{2}\epsilon^{2}}), FRECON (Algorithm 2) will find a point x𝑥x such that 𝔼​‖∇f​(𝐱)‖≤ϵ𝔼norm∇𝑓𝐱italic-ϵ\mathbb{E}\left\|\nabla f({\bm{x}})\right\|\leq\epsilon in the following number of communication rounds

T=O​(Lϵ2+(1+ω)​NS​ϵ2).𝑇𝑂𝐿superscriptitalic-ϵ21𝜔𝑁𝑆superscriptitalic-ϵ2T=O\left(\frac{L}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{(1+\omega)\sqrt{N}}{S\epsilon^{2}}\right).

From Theorem 4.1, FRECON enjoys the faster convergence result by the client-variance reduction. The total communication cost of FRECON is O​(Sϵ2+(1+ω)​Nϵ2)𝑂𝑆superscriptitalic-ϵ21𝜔𝑁superscriptitalic-ϵ2O(\frac{S}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{(1+\omega)\sqrt{N}}{\epsilon^{2}}), which matches the current state-of-the-art result of PP-MARINA in the nonconvex setting. However, PP-MARINA needs to periodically communicate with all of the clients (FP) with exact information (the uncompressed information), which is impractical in the federated learning setting, while our FRECON only needs to communicate with a subset of clients in every communication round (PP) using compressed messages.

We note that FRECON is not strictly better than COFIG. If there exists clients’ local-variance, the total communication cost of FRECON is O​(Sϵ2+(1+ω)​Nϵ2)𝑂𝑆superscriptitalic-ϵ21𝜔𝑁superscriptitalic-ϵ2O(\frac{S}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{(1+\omega)\sqrt{N}}{\epsilon^{2}}), while COFIG is O​(Sϵ2+(1+ω)​N2/3ϵ2+(1+ω)3/2​Nϵ2+(1+ω)​σ2b​ϵ4)𝑂𝑆superscriptitalic-ϵ21𝜔superscript𝑁23superscriptitalic-ϵ2superscript1𝜔32𝑁superscriptitalic-ϵ21𝜔superscript𝜎2𝑏superscriptitalic-ϵ4O(\frac{S}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{(1+\omega)N^{2/3}}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{(1+\omega)^{3/2}\sqrt{N}}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{(1+\omega)\sigma^{2}}{b\epsilon^{4}}). However,FRECON also needs to sample minibatch stochastic gradients with minibatch size b≥O​((1+ω)2​N​σ2S2​ϵ2)𝑏𝑂superscript1𝜔2𝑁superscript𝜎2superscript𝑆2superscriptitalic-ϵ2b\geq O(\frac{(1+\omega)^{2}N\sigma^{2}}{S^{2}\epsilon^{2}}) for the communicated clients in each round, while COFIG can adopt minibatch stochastic gradients with size b=1𝑏1b=1 (but also can use minibatch b>1𝑏1b>1 to decrease the total communication, see Corollary 3.3). As a result, the stochastic gradient complexity for FRECON is O​((1+ω)​Nϵ2+(1+ω)​N​σ2ϵ4)𝑂1𝜔𝑁superscriptitalic-ϵ21𝜔𝑁superscript𝜎2superscriptitalic-ϵ4O(\frac{(1+\omega)\sqrt{N}}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{(1+\omega)\sqrt{N}\sigma^{2}}{\epsilon^{4}}) by optimizing S𝑆S to be (1+ω)​N1𝜔𝑁(1+\omega)\sqrt{N}, and for COFIG is O​((1+ω)​N2/3ϵ2+(1+ω)3/2​Nϵ2+(1+ω)​σ2ϵ4)𝑂1𝜔superscript𝑁23superscriptitalic-ϵ2superscript1𝜔32𝑁superscriptitalic-ϵ21𝜔superscript𝜎2superscriptitalic-ϵ4O(\frac{(1+\omega)N^{2/3}}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{(1+\omega)^{3/2}\sqrt{N}}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{(1+\omega)\sigma^{2}}{\epsilon^{4}}) by choosing S≤(1+ω)​N2/3𝑆1𝜔superscript𝑁23S\leq(1+\omega)N^{2/3}.

5 Numerical Experiments

In this section, we show our numerical experiment results.

5.1 General setup

We run experiments on two problems: logistic regression with a nonconvex regularizer [45, 48] using the a9a dataset [3] and training ResNet-18 neural network [13] using the CIFAR10 dataset [25].

For logistic regression with a nonconvex regularizer problem, following [45, 48], the objective function for a sample (𝒂,b)𝒂𝑏({\bm{a}},b) is defined as

f​(𝒙;(𝒂,b))=log⁡(1+exp⁡(−b​𝒂⊤​𝒙))+α​∑j=1dxj21+xj2,𝑓𝒙𝒂𝑏1𝑏superscript𝒂top𝒙𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑗21superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑗2f({\bm{x}};({\bm{a}},b))=\log\left(1+\exp(-b{\bm{a}}^{\top}{\bm{x}})\right)+\alpha\sum\limits_{j=1}^{d}\frac{x_{j}^{2}}{1+x_{j}^{2}},

where the last term is the nonconvex regularizer and we choose α=0𝛼0\alpha=0 in the convex experiments and α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1 in the nonconvex experiments.

In the convex experiments (logistic regression), we compare COFIG with DIANA and EF21-PP. We include EF21-PP since we want to compare with some algorithms with partial participation, although it does not have convex analysis. In the logistic regression with nonconvex regularizer, we compare COFIG, FRECON with DIANA, EF21-PP, and PP-MARINA. In the previous experiments, we compute the local full gradient (σ=0𝜎0\sigma=0), use the theoretical learning rate, and use Natural compression operator [15] for different algorithms. Besides, we also sort the dataset to simulate the data heterogeneous setting. In the deep learning experiments, we run EF21 instead of DIANA,222We can get the hyperparameters for EF21, e.g., the learning rates, from the original paper. and we estimate the local gradient using a minibatch (σ>0𝜎0\sigma>0). Besides, we tune the learning rate to get the best convergence performance and use random sparsification compressor [46] for all algorithms in the deep learning experiment.

5.2 Binary classification with convex/nonconvex loss

In this experiment, we compare different algorithms under the theoretical step size. We consider both the convex and nonconvex problems.

Problem formulation

For logistic regression with a nonconvex regularizer problem, following [45, 48], the objective function for a sample (𝒂,b)𝒂𝑏({\bm{a}},b) is defined as

f​(𝒙;(𝒂,b))=log⁡(1+exp⁡(−b​𝒂⊤​𝒙))+α​∑j=1dxj21+xj2,𝑓𝒙𝒂𝑏1𝑏superscript𝒂top𝒙𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑗21superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑗2f({\bm{x}};({\bm{a}},b))=\log\left(1+\exp(-b{\bm{a}}^{\top}{\bm{x}})\right)+\alpha\sum\limits_{j=1}^{d}\frac{x_{j}^{2}}{1+x_{j}^{2}},

where the last term is the nonconvex regularizer. We choose α=0𝛼0\alpha=0 in the convex experiments and the problem becomes the classical logistic regression, and α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1 in the nonconvex experiments.

Computing environment

The target machine in which we have launched experiments has Intel(R) Xeon(R) Gold 6246 CPU 3.30GHz with 48 logical cores with hyper-threading and also equipped with two GeForce RTX 3090 GPU cards where each GPU has 5248 scalar FPU cores working at 1.71GHz. Each GeForce RTX 3090 GPU card has 24 GBytes of GPU DRAM memory. We conduct our experiments using the simulation framework FL_PYTorch [2] and implement EF21-PP, MARINA-PP, COFIG, and FRECON.

Description of datasets

In the following experiments, we analyze algorithms’ performance by regularized logistic regression on several LIBSVM  [3] datasets: a9a, w8a, phishing, and mushroom. The numbers of optimization variables for these datasets are as follow: 125125125 for a9a, 302302302 for w8a, 707070 for phishing, and 114114114 for mushroom. To simulate the FL settings with different data distribution, we consider two strategies: (i) uniform shuffling, where the considered datasets are randomly shuffled divided into N=100𝑁100N=100 parts (N=100𝑁100N=100 clients); and (ii) class-based sorting, where the datasets are sorted based on the label and divided into N=100𝑁100N=100 parts (that is, 50 clients hold the data with label 111 and other 50 clients hold the data with label 00).

Description of experiments

For non-convex loss experiment we set α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1 and we have compared COFIG, FRECON with PP-MARINA [9], DIANA [37, 14], EF21-PP [8]. In these experiments we have selected maximum allowable step size according to the theory of these methods in non-convex regimes. For convex loss experiments set α=0𝛼0\alpha=0 in and use convex theory of DIANA and COFIG to obtain theoretical step sizes. For EF21-PP in the (convex) logistic regression, we use its nonconvex theoretical step size since it does not have convergence analysis under the convex setting. For EF21-PP, COFIG, FRECON, and PP-MARINA in each round we sampled 101010 clients uniformly from 100100100 total clients. For DIANA, the number of clients in each round is 100100100 since it requires full participation. All algorithms run for 10 0001000010\,000 rounds. The amount of communication bits includes the amount of bits from N𝑁N clients to the master. We use Natural compressor [15] as a compression mechanism used for the communication from clients to server. In these logistic regression (and its variants) experiments, we let each client to compute the local full gradient (σ=0𝜎0\sigma=0). Table 2 summarizes the experiments settings and their corresponding results.

Experiment results

The results for Experiment #1 are presented in Figure 1. From the results, COFIG and FRECON outperform EF21-PP and DIANA, and are competitive against MARINA-PP with respect to the communication bits. From these experiments, we claim that COFIG, as a generalization of DIANA, behaves better than original DIANA. Although FRECON behaves slightly worse than PP-MARINA, but it’s important to mention that PP-MARINA need to communicate with all clients with uncompressed information periodically, and maybe impossible in practice. Results of Experiment #2 are presented in Figure 2. Although this setting is harder than the previous Experiment #1, all observations and claims made for Experiment #1 almost hold for Experiment #2. Experiments #3 and #4 demonstrate that COFIG in convex setting is practically superior than EF21-PP, DIANA in all considered LIBSVM datasets. (See Figure 3 and Figure 4). The class-based sorting setting for binary classification if the number of clients is even and each client has the same number of datapoint will essentially mean that each client has training samples corresponding only to one class. Without collaboration with other clients and using only local data points the training process organized through optimization of fi​(x)subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥f_{i}(x) is meaningless for any client i𝑖i, and we want to highlight that in this extreme case, collaboration between clients is required.

5.3 Image classification with neural nets

In this experiment we train ResNet-18 [13] on the CIFAR10 dataset [25]. The dimension of optimization problem d=11 173 962𝑑11173962d=11\,173\,962, from which 11 159 2321115923211\,159\,232 optimization variables come from training parameters of cross correlation operators Conv2d, 9 60096009\,600 optimization variables comes from training Batch Normalization layers, and finally, 5 13051305\,130 optimization variables come from training last linear FC layer.

The sizes of the training and validation set are 50​K50𝐾50K and 10​K10𝐾10K records. Similar to the heterogeneous binary classification experiments, the CIFAR10 dataset has been partitioned heterogeneously across 101010 clients, where each client contains the data of a single class and there are 10 classes in total (i.e., class-based sorting).

Problem formulation

We define fi​(𝒙)subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙f_{i}({\bm{x}}) to be local empirical risk associated with the local data, 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖{\mathcal{D}}_{i} stored on client i𝑖i. The loss, fi​(𝒙)subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙f_{i}({\bm{x}}) is a standard unweighted cross-entropy loss constructed with using output from neural network:

(6) f​(𝒙)𝑓𝒙\displaystyle f({\bm{x}}) ==def​1N​∑i=1Nfi​(𝒙)def==1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙\displaystyle\overset{\mathrm{def}}{=\joinrel=}\dfrac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}({\bm{x}})
(7) fi​(𝒙)subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙\displaystyle f_{i}({\bm{x}}) =1Ni​∑j=1NiCrossEntropyLoss​(b(j),g​(a(j),𝒙)).absent1subscript𝑁𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑖CrossEntropyLosssuperscript𝑏𝑗𝑔superscript𝑎𝑗𝒙\displaystyle=\dfrac{1}{N_{i}}\sum_{j=1}^{N_{i}}\text{CrossEntropyLoss}(b^{(j)},g(a^{(j)},{\bm{x}})).

Here a(j)∈ℝ3×28×28superscript𝑎𝑗superscriptℝ32828a^{(j)}\in\mathbb{R}^{3\times 28\times 28} is input image, b(j)∈{e1,…,e10}superscript𝑏𝑗subscript𝑒1…subscript𝑒10b^{(j)}\in\{e_{1},\dots,e_{10}\} is one one-hot encoding of class label, Ni=|𝒟i|subscript𝑁𝑖subscript𝒟𝑖N_{i}=|{\mathcal{D}}_{i}|, and g𝑔g is a neural networks parameterized by unknown variable 𝒙𝒙{\bm{x}}. Neural network g​(⋅,𝒙)𝑔⋅𝒙g(\cdot,{\bm{x}}) obtains input image a(j)superscript𝑎𝑗a^{(j)} and produces vector ℝ10superscriptℝ10\mathbb{R}^{10} in probability simplex.

Description of experiment

In this experiment, we random shuffle the CIFAR10 dataset to avoid the problematic behavior of Batch Normalization in ResNet-18. The step sizes for different algorithms are tuned from the following set L​Rs​e​t𝐿subscript𝑅𝑠𝑒𝑡{LR}_{set} to get fastest convergence:

(8) L​Rs​e​t=𝐿subscript𝑅𝑠𝑒𝑡absent\displaystyle{LR}_{set}= {0.1,0.06,0.03,0.01,0.006,0.003,0.001,0.0006,\displaystyle\{0.1,0.06,0.03,0.01,0.006,0.003,0.001,0.0006,
0.0003,0.0001,0.00006,0.00003,0.00001}.\displaystyle\quad 0.0003,0.0001,0.00006,0.00003,0.00001\}.

In this experiment, we compare EF21, EF21-PP, COFIG, FRECON, and PP-MARINA. We divide the dataset into 101010 parts (N=10𝑁10N=10 clients), and each client holds 500050005000 samples. For EF21-PP, COFIG, FRECON, and PP-MARINA, we test both cases for S=1𝑆1S=1 and S=2𝑆2S=2. We use the RandK [46] compressor with K=0.05​D𝐾0.05𝐷K=0.05D for all algorithms, where D𝐷D is the number of parameters for ResNet-18. Unlike the previous binary classification experiments, in this deep learning experiments, different algorithms cannot access the local full gradients from the clients (σ>0𝜎0\sigma>0). When the algorithms need the local full gradients, each client estimates the gradient using a minibatch with size b=500𝑏500b=500 (10%percent1010\% of the local data).

Experiment results

The results for this image classification deep learning experiments are presented in Figure 5 and Figure 6 with S=1𝑆1S=1 and S=2𝑆2S=2, respectively. In our experiments, we observe that PP-MARINA is practically impossible in those circumstances. Besides, the performance of FRECON is similar to EF21-PP, and our COFIG converges fastest among all these algorithms. For FRECON we have tuned parameter λ𝜆\lambda from trying several values in [0,1]01[0,1] we have found that for training this NN the value λ=0.75𝜆0.75\lambda=0.75 leads to more fast convergence. In Figure 7 there is a comparison with full participated version EF21, and our COFIG converges faster as well in terms of the communication bits.

We attribute the results to the fact that COFIG works better with local variance (Section 2.1) compared with FRECON. It is also worth noting that based on our hyperparameter search, we observe that for FRECON, S=1𝑆1S=1 (Figure 5) can use a larger learning rate than S=2𝑆2S=2 (Figure 6), which reflect that FRECON may not work very well or unstable when the local variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} (Section 2.1) is somewhat large. Besides, EF21-PP, FRECON, and COFIG all perform better than the full participation algorithm EF21 in terms of the communicate bits (Figure 7), which shows that partial participation may indeed speed up the convergence in terms of the total communication bits.

This experiment shows that when the number of local data is large, and we can not compute the local full gradient, COFIG may behave best. Together with the previous experiments, COFIG can be set up as a default optimization algorithm for federated learning applications, and then divert to FRECON if we have further information, e.g., we can compute the local full gradient and/or the number of clients is very large.

5.4 Remarks for experiments

According to both logistic regression (with nonconvex regularizer) and the image classification deep learning experiments, we validate the effectiveness of our proposed algorithms COFIG and FRECON. However, the algorithms still have their own advantages in different settings. In short, we summarize the following messages:

  1. 1.

    For problems where we can estimate the local gradients fairly accurately (i.e., the local variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} is small), FRECON performs better than COFIG in terms of the communication bits. This trend is also corroborated by the faster theoretical convergence rate of FRECON when σ2=0superscript𝜎20\sigma^{2}=0 (Theorem 4.1).

  2. 2.

    When optimizing large-scale neural networks like ResNet that has a relatively large local variance , COFIG performs better than FRECON in terms of the communication bits. This trend is supported by the convergence results of COFIG and FRECON (Theorem 3.2 and 4.1), where COFIG has a smaller dependency with respect to σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} than FRECON. The large dependency on σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} may incur some unstable behaviors when training large neural networks.

6 Conclusion

In this paper, we introduce COFIG and FRECON, which successfully incorporate communication compression with client-variance reduction for dealing with large number of heterogeneous clients in federated learning. Our FRECON obtains the best communication complexity for federated nonconvex setting, and our COFIG gives the first theoretical convergence result for federated non-strongly convex setting that supports both communication compression and partial participation, while previous works either obtain worse convergence results or require full clients communication.
